title: 115_s2018
content: The "American Family Act of 2017" establishes a fully refundable Child Tax Credit by eliminating the existing credit and inserting a new section 36C in the Internal Revenue Code. The "American Family Act of 2017" introduces a new Child Tax Credit allowing a credit against the tax for each qualifying child of the taxpayer, based on their age and deduction eligibility. The Child Tax Credit under the "American Family Act of 2017" provides an increased amount for qualifying children under 6 years old with a deduction. The credit is subject to reduction based on the taxpayer's income exceeding a certain threshold. The Child Tax Credit amount is reduced based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income exceeding a threshold amount, which is $110,000 for joint filers. The threshold amount for the Child Tax Credit is $110,000 for joint filers, $75,000 for individuals not married, and $55,000 for married individuals filing separately, determined by marital status under section 7703. The applicable amount for the Child Tax Credit is determined by dividing the credit amount by $20, multiplied by $20. The Child Tax Credit amount is determined by dividing the credit by $20, multiplied by the total number of qualifying children of the taxpayer. A qualifying child is defined as a child under 19 years of age as per section 152(c). The term 'qualifying child' refers to a child under 19 years of age as defined in section 152(c), excluding certain non-citizens. Starting from 2018, there will be an inflation adjustment for the $3,000 amount in subsection (a)(1) of the Child Tax Credit. In 2018, an inflation adjustment will increase the $3,000 amount in subsection (a)(1) of the Child Tax Credit for taxable years beginning after 2017. The Child Tax Credit amount will be adjusted for inflation in 2018, with any increase rounded to the nearest multiple of $50. Taxpayers must meet identification requirements for qualifying children to claim the credit. The Child Tax Credit amount will be adjusted for inflation in 2018, rounded to the nearest multiple of $50. Taxpayers must meet identification requirements for qualifying children to claim the credit. Taxpayers must have a valid taxpayer identification number issued before the due date for filing the return to claim the Child Tax Credit. The credit is not allowed for taxable years less than 12 months, except in cases of a taxpayer's death. Restrictions apply to taxpayers who improperly claimed the credit in prior years. No credit allowed for taxable years less than 12 months. Restrictions on taxpayers who improperly claimed credit in prior years. The disallowance period for claiming credit under this section is 10 taxable years after a final determination of fraud, or 2 taxable years after a final determination of improper claim in prior years. The disallowance period for claiming credit under this section is 10 taxable years after a final determination of fraud, or 2 taxable years after a final determination of reckless or intentional disregard of rules and regulations. Taxpayers making improper prior claims may be denied credit under this section. Taxpayers denied credit for improper claims must provide necessary information to demonstrate eligibility for the credit in subsequent years. The credit allowed for a taxable year will be reduced by any advance payments received. The credit allowed for a taxable year will be reduced by any advance payments received under section 7527A, and excess advance payments will increase the tax imposed for that year. If the advance payments exceed the allowed credit for the taxable year, the tax imposed will be increased by the excess amount. "SEC. 7527A. ADVANCE PAYMENT OF CHILD TAX CREDIT." The Secretary will establish a program for advance monthly payments of the child tax credit to eligible taxpayers, with limitations on the total amount per taxpayer for the taxable year. The Secretary may only make payments under subsection (a) if the total amount to any taxpayer in a taxable year does not exceed the excess of the amount determined under section 36C over the estimated tax imposed by subtitle A. The program described in subsection (a) will make efforts to apply the limitation of section 36C(b) for payments made under the program. The program described in subsection (a) will make reasonable efforts to apply the limitation of section 36C(b) for payments made under the program. Conforming amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by removing section 24 and adding a new section after section 36B in subpart C of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of subtitle A. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by adding a new section after section 36B in subpart C of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of subtitle A, titled "Sec. 36C. Child tax credit." The table of sections for chapter 77 is also amended accordingly. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new section titled "Sec. 7527A. Advance payment of child tax credit." This section modifies certain provisions related to taxes paid under agreements with foreign affiliates and updates references in the Code. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to update references in various sections, including sections 152(f)(6)(B)(ii), 501(c)(26), 6211(b)(4)(A), and 6213(g)(2), by replacing mentions of "section 24" with "section 36C" for child tax credit purposes. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to update references in various sections by replacing mentions of "section 24" with "section 36C" for child tax credit purposes. Amendments include changes to sections 6211(b)(4)(A), 6213(g)(2), and 1324(b) of the Code. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to update references by replacing "section 24" with "section 36C" for child tax credit purposes. Amendments include changes to section 1324(b) of the Code, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2016.
